nodes.content:
The objective of online business owners is to maximize revenue, which can be achieved through a user-friendly shopping experience for customers (utilizing popular marketplaces like Advanced Product Feeds extension).

How a newly placed order is managed in a Magento 2 store is a smooth and streamlined process. Magento 2 provides a smooth and streamlined process for selecting and purchasing products. Customers can easily browse the shop catalog, choose their desired items, set the quantity select any available options, and then add the items to their cart. During the order process, Customers provide their shipping and billing information, choose their preferred payment and delivery methods, and then finalize the purchase. Understanding how a newly placed purchase is managed in a Magento 2 store is crucial for effective management.

Once an order is placed, Magento 2’s powerful order management system takes over. A temporary order record is created in the database, and the order status is initially set as “pending” in the order grid. This is where the Magento 2 order processing workflow and Magento 2 order management features come into play.

Magento 2’s order management system offers a range of functionalities for managing orders, including processing payments, fulfilling orders, and managing shipping. By utilizing these features, businesses can streamline their order fulfillment process and improve customer satisfaction.

One of the benefits of Magento 2’s management system is the ability to cancel a pending purchase at any time before payment. This makes the purchase process more flexible and convenient for customers. By utilizing Magento 2’s management features, businesses can provide an exceptional customer experience and manage their sales more efficiently.

The order management system of Magento 2 provides a comprehensive solution for businesses seeking to manage their order management operations effectively, including Magento 2 order management functionalities such as processing payments, fulfilling orders, and managing shipping. By utilizing these features, businesses can streamline their sales fulfillment process and enhance customer satisfaction.

The platform enables efficient management of the entire lifecycle of purchases, from creating and processing to shipping and invoicing, providing businesses with complete visibility and control over their management processes, specifically the Magento 2 management process. Understanding how a newly placed order is managed in the Magento 2 store is crucial for optimizing the fulfillment process and improving overall business performance. Therefore, Magento 2 is an ideal platform for businesses looking to efficiently manage their orders and enhance their customers’ experience.

By utilizing Magento 2’s management features, businesses can provide an exceptional customer experience and manage their sales more efficiently. One of the benefits of Magento 2’s management system is the ability to cancel a pending purchase at any time before payment. This makes the purchase process more flexible and convenient for customers.

Once payment is received, the store manager can create an invoice and begin shipment. How a newly placed order is managed in the Magento 2 store is a critical aspect of maximizing revenue as it ensures the seamless and efficient processing of orders, from confirming payment to shipping to the customer.

How a Newly Placed Order is Managed in Magento 2 Store: A Guide

The Default Processing Path of an Order

The sequence of steps involved in processing may vary depending on a store’s business practices. Here is a typical processing flow:

  • Placement: The customer completes their shopping and clicks the checkout button on the checkout page, triggering the start of processing.
  • Registration: The system creates a new one with a “pending” status, waiting for payment confirmation. The store manager can edit or cancel the before payment.
  • Payment received: Upon payment confirmation by the store manager, the status changes to “Processing”. The customer may receive a notification from their chosen payment provider about the transaction status.
  • Invoice creation: The store creates an invoice for the customer after receiving payment, with options varying based on the payment method used. A copy of the invoice is sent to the customer.
  • Shipment: The store manager arranges for shipment, and creates a packing slip, and shipping label. The customer is notified of the shipment and can track the package using a tracking service in their account.

Limitations of Magento in Order Management

A common scenario for a store is the need to modify order details, whether due to incomplete information from the customer during checkout, changes in information during processing, or the customer’s request to add or change products. Understanding how a newly placed order is managed in the Magento 2 store is important to ensure that these modifications can be made efficiently and accurately, without compromising the customer experience.

However, Magento 2 has a limitation where data cannot be altered once it is processed in the backend and stored in the database.

To overcome the limitations of managing in the backend, stores can use the Magento Management extension. This tool enhances the backend management system’s flexibility in handling. Store managers can easily modify existing orders without having to cancel them first. They can manage current requests, add items, impose restrictions, and more, saving time and reducing errors. How To Make Order Status Visible on Frontend in Magento 2 is also a crucial aspect for customers, as it provides them with real-time updates on the status of their orders, ensuring a smooth and transparent purchasing experience.

Conclusion

In conclusion, understanding how a newly placed order is managed in a Magento 2 store is crucial for effective order management. Fortunately, the process can be streamlined with the use of the Magento Order Management extension. This tool provides store managers with the ability to modify existing orders with ease, reducing errors and saving time. With this extension, the limitations of the backend management system in Magento 2 can be overcome, making order management more efficient and effective. Overall, the Magento Order Management extension is a valuable addition for stores looking to improve their order management process, especially for managing newly placed orders.

nodes.content:
New stores may confuse customers to navigate through the site with the new options available, and because of this product search proce ss will become longer. Therefore, Product labeling is a crucial aspect of e-commerce as it helps to effectively communicate information about the product to potential customers. To make it easier, you can create configurable product in Magento 2 which will allow customers to easily choose the desired product options.

In Magento 2, an open-source e-commerce platform, creating and configuring product labels is made easy with its user-friendly interface and features. This blog will guide you through the process of how to configure and design Product Labels in Magento 2.

Steps to Configure and Design Product Labels in Magento 2

Step 1: Enable Product Labels

The first step to creating product labels in Magento 2 is to enable them. To do this, navigate to the Magento 2 backend and go to Stores > Configuration > Catalog > Product Label. In the Product Label section, set the “Enabled” option to “Yes.” This will enable the product labels in your Magento 2 store.

Step 2: Create a New Label

Once the product labels are enabled, the next step is to create a new label. To create a new label, go to Marketing > Product Labels in the Magento 2 backend. In the Product Labels section, click on the “Add New Label” button. A form will appear where you can fill in the label information such as the label name, status, and conditions for the label to display.

Step 3: Configure Label Display Options

The next step is to configure the display options for the label. In the Magento 2 backend, navigate to Marketing > Product Labels and select the label you want to configure. In the label configuration page, you can set the position of the label on the product page, the font size, and the text color. Additionally, you can choose to add an image to the label. You can also preview the label to see how it will look on the product page.

Step 4: Set Conditions for Label Display

In order to display the label on the product page, conditions need to be set. Conditions can be based on product attributes such as price, special price, and stock status. You can also set a start and end date for the label to be displayed. These conditions will determine when the label will be displayed on the product page.

Step 5: Preview Label

Before applying the label to a product, it is important to preview the label to ensure it meets your expectations. To preview the label, go to Marketing > Product Labels in the Magento 2 backend and select the label you want to preview. In the label configuration page, click on the “Preview” button to see how the label will look on the product page.

Step 6: Save and Apply Label

The final step is to save the label and apply it to a product. To apply the label, go to Catalog > Products in the Magento 2 backend. In the Products section, select the product you want to apply the label to and click on the “Edit” button. In the Product Information section, select the label from the “Product Label” dropdown and save the product. The label will now be displayed on the product page.

Conclusion:

Product labeling is a crucial aspect of e-commerce as it helps to effectively communicate information about the product to potential customers. Magento 2 makes it easy to create and configure product labels with its user-friendly interface and features. By following the steps outlined in this blog, you can set up and design product labels in Magento 2 with ease.

nodes.excerpt: Every successful business enterprise knows that the customer is at the center of everything they do. Providing the best customer experience is key to increasing profits. That’s why integrating Zoho CRM with Magento 2 can be a game changer. This powerful combination provides an efficient solution for managing customer data and sales processes. By integrating … Read more
nodes.content:
Every successful business enterprise knows that the customer is at the center of everything they do. Providing the best customer experience is key to increasing profits. That’s why integrating Zoho CRM with Magento 2 can be a game changer. This powerful combination provides an efficient solution for managing customer data and sales processes.

By integrating these two platforms, you can streamline the sales process, improve communication with your customers, and boost overall efficiency. This blog is here to help you navigate the integration process step-by-step so that you can easily learn how to Integrate ZOHO CRM with Magento 2 and take your business to the next level.

What is ZOHO CRM

Zoho CRM is a cutting-edge cloud-based CRM software specifically developed for businesses of all sizes, offering a comprehensive platform for managing customer interactions, sales processes, and customer data. With its advanced features such as lead management, contact management, opportunity management, and more, Zoho CRM empowers businesses to track and analyze customer interactions, streamline sales processes, and enhance communication with customers.

This software is highly accessible, requiring only an internet connection for use, and can be effortlessly integrated with other business tools and applications, providing seamless compatibility with existing systems. Through the use of Zoho CRM, businesses can maximize their productivity, gain valuable insights, and provide an exceptional customer experience.

Steps to Integrate ZOHO CRM with Magento 2

Step 1: Set up a Zoho CRM account

The first step in integrating Zoho CRM with Magento 2 is to set up a Zoho CRM account if you haven’t already. Zoho CRM is a cloud-based customer relationship management solution that enables businesses to manage their customer interactions, sales processes, and more. To set up a Zoho CRM account, simply go to the Zoho CRM website and sign up for a free trial.Now create new zoho client I’d.

Step 2: Install the Zoho CRM Magento 2 extension

The next step is to install the Zoho CRM Magento 2 extension. This extension will help automate the process of syncing data between Zoho CRM and Magento 2. To install the extension, go to the Magento Marketplace and search for the “Zoho CRM” extension. Click on the “Install” button to install the extension and then follow the instructions to configure the settings as needed. If you don’t know how to install extension in magento 2 then you can read guide about install extension in magento 2 .

Step 3: Configure Zoho CRM API

In order to connect Zoho CRM with Magento 2, you will need to create an API key in Zoho CRM. The API key will be used to authenticate the connection between Zoho CRM and Magento 2. To create the API key, log in to your Zoho CRM account and go to the API section. Here, you can create a new API key by clicking on the “Generate” button.

Step 4: Connect Zoho CRM with Magento 2

Now that you have created the API key, you can connect Zoho CRM with Magento 2. To do this, go to the Zoho CRM configuration section in Magento 2 and enter the API key you created in step 3. In addition, you can configure the synchronization settings as per your requirements. For example, you can choose to synchronize specific data such as customer information, order information, and more.

Step 5: Test the integration

To ensure that the integration between Zoho CRM and Magento 2 is working correctly, it is recommended to perform a test. You can create a test order in Magento 2 and check if it is reflected in Zoho CRM. Similarly, you can create a lead in Zoho CRM and check if it is reflected in Magento 2. This will help you confirm that the data is being synced correctly between the two platforms.

Step 6: Monitor and adjust the integration

Once the integration is set up and working correctly, it is important to continuously monitor it to ensure that the data is being synced correctly. If you encounter any issues, you can adjust the configuration settings as needed to resolve them. Regular monitoring will also help you identify any potential problems and make the necessary adjustments to keep the integration working smoothly.

Conclusion

To sum up, integrating Zoho CRM with Magento 2 is a simple and straightforward process that can offer immense advantages to businesses seeking to streamline their customer data and sales processes. By carefully following the steps outlined in this blog, you can easily set up and configure the integration to perfectly fit your unique requirements.

nodes.excerpt: How to Use the API Framework in Magento 2 to Expand the Store Capabilities – An API (Application Programming Interface) is a commonly used tool that enhances an application’s functionality by enabling it to communicate with other software. Magento, like many others, heavily relies on APIs. How to use the API framework in Magento 2 … Read more
nodes.content:
How to Use the API Framework in Magento 2 to Expand the Store Capabilities – An API (Application Programming Interface) is a commonly used tool that enhances an application’s functionality by enabling it to communicate with other software. Magento, like many others, heavily relies on APIs.

How to use the API framework in Magento 2 to expand store capabilities: A Guide

What is Magento API

Magento exchanges a substantial amount of data in its day-to-day operations through various applications and services that aim to provide a seamless buying experience for customers. The interaction between Magento 2 and external tools utilizing this Adobe platform is facilitated through APIs. So, what is API in Magento 2? An API (Application Programming Interface) is a set of protocols, routines, and tools that allows different software applications to communicate with each other. Although recently implemented, APIs have become widely adopted in Magento.

The customer Application Programming Interface in Magento streamlines the data exchange process and simplifies the tasks of receiving, sending, processing information, and transferring it to external systems for both store managers and customers. How to Use the API Framework in Magento 2 to Expand the Store Capabilities? Without the API, manual export and import of all the necessary data for store operations would be time-consuming.

Fundamental Principles of API Functionality in Magento

Magento 2 and its predecessor, Magento 1, support two popular APIs: REST (Representational State Transfer) and SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol). In this article, we focus on REST, which is easier to use compared to SOAP.

To use the API framework in it, the first step is to specify the URL in the webapi.xml file located in the /vendor/etc folder. This file also defines the methods and services the API can use in the future.

Once the required definitions are specified in the webapi.xml file, it is dynamically rendered and integrated into the web API. What is the use of API in Magento 2? APIs serve as the primary means of communication between Magento 2 and external tools utilizing this Adobe platform. The file and its contents are managed programmatically, so it’s essential to have a well-organized help class.

When Magento makes an API call, the request includes several data elements:

1. HTTP request type (POST, GET, PUT, DELETE)

2. URL of the endpoint to which the request is sent

3. Payload, which consists of parameters for the request execution (optional for some API calls), passed through the request in JSON or XML format

4. Body information, including rendering HTTP request and response headers, authorization requests, cache, and cookies.

Swagger demonstrates all the programmatic methods that can be used with a particular installation and provides real-time updates of the store data. Additionally, it allows for immediate verification of API call values through straightforward endpoint execution peculiarities that run directly from a web browser.

To use Swagger with REST API, a store owner simply needs to add “swagger” to their website URL, for example, http://store.com/swagger. This opens the door to using REST API with Swagger and provides a page to track all the programmatic methods available for guest users.”

What is the utilization of the web APIs provided by Magento?

The API offered by Magento allows store owners to perform various programmatic tasks, including:

  • Developing a shopping app for smartphones
  • Integrating with CRM or ERP systems like Salesforce or Xero
  • Integrating with a content management system (excluding content tagging)
  • Using AJAX calls via JavaScript to access third-party functions in the Magento storefront and admin panel.

There’s more to the API in Magento.

The API in Magento offers much more than what has been listed so far. The software interface defines three user types to differentiate API access.

Guest mode user

In Magento 2, the Guest mode user is an anonymous user level that grants limited access to resources through the API’s anonymous permissions. This mode enables users who have not created an account or logged in to access some features of the online store without going through the registration process. However, the functionality available to Guest mode users is restricted, and they cannot perform certain actions that require authorization or authentication. Despite these limitations, Guest mode provides a quick and easy way for customers to browse products, view prices, and add items to their cart without the need for a full account.

Administrative user level

The Administrative user level in Magento 2 grants extensive access to resources within the system. This includes access to all data related to the online store, such as orders, customers, products, and categories. Administrative users can modify and manipulate data, including creating, deleting, and updating resources within the store. This user level is intended for store managers and other authorized personnel who need access to advanced features and tools to manage the store’s operations effectively. The specific resources and permissions available to administrative users are determined by the configuration files, which can be customized to meet the specific needs of the business. Overall, the administrative user level is critical for the smooth operation and management of a Magento 2 store.

Customer

To control access for different types of users, authorization is required. it provides three options for authentication to ensure specific levels of access are granted to each user.

Authentication through tokens

This method provides access credentials, such as a username, password, and token, during the initial connection setup. Once the connection is established, the exchange of data is authorized solely through the token, which has a limited lifespan.

Access per session

The session-based validation of access offered by Magento is considered one of the simplest authorization methods among the three. The API relies on session data to grant access to designated resources. To authorize frontend client access, log in and direct the browser to the page with the URL https://store.com./rest/V1/clients/me. This will grant self and guest-level access to the assets for clients who visit the specified page while accessing the store. This mechanism also applies to administrator accounts if they attempt to access resources they are authorized to use.

Authenticating a user via an OAuth

The API functionality in Magento can be accessed using the OAuth 1.0a specification. With this approach, Magento’s API acts as a service provider, allowing external users access to resources through authorization granted by the resource owners.

How to start using Magento 2 API

To get started with Magento API, you need to register for the web service in the Magento admin panel. Follow these steps to enable the service:

1. Create a web services user on Magento Admin – Use the tools provided in the admin panel to create a user for the service.

2. Create a new integration – Open the menu System > Extensions > Integration > Add New Integration and restrict the integration’s resource access list.

3. Set up authentication – A store admin can configure the access authentication using a client with REST or SOAP support. If token validation is used, navigate to the menu System > Permission > All Users > Add New User to create a new client. This step may not be necessary with the other two authentication methods.

Conclusion

In conclusion, utilizing the web APIs provided by Magento can enhance the functionality of your online store by allowing for programmatic tasks, integration with various systems, and customization through the use of AJAX calls. What is Magento Framework in PHP? It is a popular e-commerce platform that provides these web APIs. The API in it offers different levels of access for guests, administrative users, and customers, and offers three mechanisms for authentication including token-based, session-based, and OAuth 1.0a.

How to Use the API Framework in Magento 2 to Expand the Store Capabilities? To get started, the store owner must register for the web service, create a web services user, make a new integration, and set up authentication within the Magento Framework in PHP.

nodes.content:
Have you thought about the amount of time a typical software engineer spends just setting up a reliable work tool configuration? The answer varies from one company to another, as it depends on the software stack being used and the availability of documentation. If you’re looking to install Magento 2 on Docker, you might be interested in knowing that it can help reduce the time spent on configuring the work tool and increase efficiency in software builds. Most engineers, regardless of the industry or stack they use, can relate to the difficulties of setting up a working system. Some have even seen their team struggle with it. If you’re interested in learning how to install Magento 2 on Docker, there are plenty of resources available online to help you get started.

When setting up Magento 2, there are numerous advantages to consider, such as reduced time spent on configuring the work tool and increased efficiency in software builds. What are the Reasons to Set up Magento 2 on Docker? This is a question worth considering as it can greatly benefit teams in terms of productivity and collaboration. The advantages of using a containerization platform become more noticeable when working in a team, as it enables the work configuration to be set up quickly, allowing software builds to start being produced in no time.

What are the Reasons to Set up Magento 2 on Docker?

If a developer is considering configuring Magento 2 using a containerization platform, the following reasons can help make a decision. What are the Reasons to set up Magento 2 on Docker? Here are some key justifications for setting up Magento software in a containerized environment, it provides a consistent development and testing environment that is portable across different machines, operating systems, and cloud platforms. It enables developers to quickly create and destroy test environments, reducing setup time and increasing productivity. Docker also allows for easier scaling of infrastructure as needed, and simplifies the deployment of updates and changes to the Magento 2 website. Additionally, it provides isolation and security for the application and its dependencies, helping to ensure that the application runs reliably and securely in production. Overall, setting up Magento 2 on Docker can provide numerous benefits for developers and organizations looking to streamline their development and deployment processes:

  • Enhancing the development process makes it a seamless experience, and the mobility and flexibility make it perfect for developing Magento 2.
  • Easy installation and user-friendly.
  • The software can be installed on a local computer for a quick start to the development.
  • The reliability of streamlined development greatly benefits PHP-based applications, including Magento.

Installing Magento 2 on Docker: A Step-by-Step Guide

Local environment setup.

The first step in the configuration process is to secure an account on the Adobe Commerce website. If you already have an account, there is no need to create a new one. Log in to your Adobe Commerce account and create or copy the existing authentication keys. Your account may already have these keys, as it is used for the Magento Marketplace.

Verify the system requirements.

Depending on the specific use case, a paid subscription may be required. Professional users in businesses with 250 employees or more and annual revenue exceeding $10 million cannot use it for free.

Docker has the following system configuration requirements:

For Windows:

The host system for containers can be Windows 11 or Windows 10, including Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education editions.

Windows 11 should be no older than 21H2, Windows 10 should be built 19041 for Home or Pro, and build 18363 for Enterprise or Education editions.

The operating system should have WSL 2 subsystem installed or Hyper-V. Windows features for containers must be enabled.

There are no strict hardware requirements, but the machine should be capable of running WSL 2 on Windows 10 and 11, meaning it should have a 64-bit processor with Second Level Address Translation (SLAT) support and at least 4GB of RAM. Virtualization should be enabled in the BIOS.

For Mac:

  • The computer should have an Intel x86 processor.
  • macOS 10.15 or newer (Catalina, Big Sur, Monterey).
  • 4 GB of RAM.
  • VirtualBox 4.3.30 or older must be uninstalled as it is incompatible with Docker.
  • Owners of Mac computers with Apple M1 ARM processors should use the Rosetta 2 translator to run Docker.

Docker setup

To properly configure and run a containerized environment, the Compose tool is necessary. This software utility enables the definition and deployment of multi-container applications. With Compose, a specific YAML file is used to configure the app’s setup. Then, with a single command line, it is possible to create and start all the defined services. See the list of Compose features for information on its functions. Compose is compatible with all software systems for software development, testing, and production. Check the official documentation for common use cases. The process for using Compose consists of three steps:

1. Define your app’s current configuration using a specific Dockerfile, which can be reused later.

2. Set up all required services for the app to run by using the docker-compose.yml file. This allows running the app in a detached software environment.

3. Run the Docker commands to create and compose the app, or launch it using the docker-compose binary.

Refer to the template for the docker-compose.yml file to use in your configuration.

version: “3.9”  # optional since v1.27.0

services:

  web:

    build: .

    ports:

 – “5000:5000”

    volumes:

 – .:/code

 – logvolume01:/var/log

    links:

 – redis

  redis:

    image: redis

volumes:

  logvolume01: {}

To install it on Mac computers, follow these steps:

  • Download a local copy of the Docker.dmg file.
  • Open the app installer by double-clicking on the downloaded Docker installation package and dragging it to the applications folder.
  • Go to the Applications folder and start it by double-clicking on its Docker.app file.
  • A Docker menu will appear on the screen with the service conditions and user agreement. Accept the agreement to gain access to it.

To install on a desktop Windows computer, follow these steps:

  • Download the official installation file from the Docker Hub website. It will typically be saved in your browser’s default download folder, which is the system download folder.
  • Double-click the downloaded file to begin the installation process. Ensure that Hyper-V and WSL 2 are enabled on your system. If they are not, install them.
  • Follow the instructions of the setup wizard to complete the installation, and then click Close.
  • If your current user account doesn’t have admin access, add it to the “docker-users” group. To do this, open the Windows Computer Management tool as an administrator, navigate to Local Users and Groups > Groups > Docker-users, right-click on the option, and add your current user to the Docker group. Log out and log back in for the changes to take effect.

To install on a Windows Server, follow these steps:

  1. Open an elevated PowerShell by right-clicking on the PowerShell app and selecting “Run as administrator”. Confirm the prompt to allow changes to your device.

2. In PowerShell, run the following command to set the required security protocol: [Net.ServicePointManager]:: SecurityProtocol = [Net.SecurityProtocolType]:: Tls12

3. Download the latest stable version of Compose (v1.29.2) by running the following command:

Invoke-WebRequest "https://github.com/docker/compose/releases/download/1.29.2/docker-compose-Windows-x86_64.exe" -UseBasicParsing -OutFile $Env:ProgramFiles\Docker\docker-compose.exe

Note: On Windows Server 2019, you can place the Compose executable in $Env:ProgramFiles\Docker. This directory is included in the system PATH, so you can run the “docker-compose –version” command in the next step without any additional setup.

To install a version other than 1.29.2 of Compose, replace 1.29.2 with the desired version in the command used to download Compose.

Verify the installation.

docker-compose --version

docker-compose version 1.29.2, build 01110ad01

To install on a Linux environment, follow these steps:

Download the latest stable release of Docker Compose by running the following command:

sudo curl -L "https://github.com/docker/compose/releases/download/1.29.2/docker-compose-$(uname -s)-$(uname -m)" -o /usr/local/bin/docker-compose

To install a different version of Compose, replace 1.29.2 with the desired version in the command.

Make the binary executable by running the following command: 

sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/docker-compose

If the installation of Docker-Compose results in the failure of the “docker-compose” command, verify your system’s PATH. You can also create a symbolic link to the “/usr/bin” directory or another directory included in your PATH. An example of this process is:

sudo ln -s /usr/local/bin/docker-compose /usr/bin/docker-compose

Additionally, you can install command completion for the bash and zsh shell (optional). To check the success of your installation, run the following command:

docker-compose –version

Start Docker instance

Now that you’ve reached this step, you’ll need to open your terminal to the directory where it is located (e.g., /path/to/docker). It’s time to start your virtual machine. It may take a few minutes for it to download the images, but future startups will only take a few seconds.

To start your virtual machine, run the following command:

docker-compose up -d --build

Ensure that everything is running according to your plan.

Procedure for Installing Magento 2 in Docker Environment

  • To access the command line in your Docker web, run the following command: docker exec -it web bash.
  • Once you are in the web document root by using cd /app, it is optional but highly recommended to install the sample data by running php bin/magento sample data: deploy.

For step-by-step instructions on how to install Magento 2 via Composer, refer to our article.

Note – After setting up a clear Magento installation, you may opt to install any additional extensions such as layered navigation extension.

  • To access your Docker web, use the following command in your command line: docker exec -it web bash. Then navigate to the web document root with the command: cd /app.

Optionally, deploy sample data using the command: php bin/magento sample data: deploy. Follow our article to learn how to install Magento 2.4 via Composer.

When visiting your website for the first time at https://local.domain.com or your chosen domain, it may take a few minutes to load the page as nothing is cached and the Magento system generates files upon loading. Subsequent visits should be quicker. Please note that the web container uses a self-signed SSL certificate, which may result in a security alert from your browser.

You have successfully set up Magento 2 on Docker! Once you are ready to take your website live, you can easily Move Magento 2 from Localhost to Server. Use our step-by-step guide to repeat the process for future projects. Congratulations!

Conclusion

In conclusion, following these steps can help you successfully set up Magento 2 on Docker. By using it, you can easily create, deploy and manage applications in a virtual environment, making the development process smoother and more efficient. What are the reasons to set up Magento 2 on Docker? Docker allows for consistent development and testing environments across different machines, operating systems, and cloud platforms. It also provides a scalable infrastructure that can be easily scaled up or down as needed, and it allows for faster and more efficient deployment of updates and changes to your Magento 2 website. Keep in mind that the first time you access your website, it may take some time to load, but subsequent visits will be faster. Additionally, if you need to install additional extensions, you can do so easily with the clear Magento installation you have created. Overall, the process is straightforward and the result is a fully functional Magento 2 website running on it.

nodes.title: How to Change the Language of Magento 2 Admin Panel
nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is a powerful e-commerce platform that provides store owners with a wide range of features and tools to manage their online stores. One of the key features of Magento 2 is the ability to switch the language of the platform to better serve customers from different regions and cultures. Additionally, it also has … Read more
nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a powerful e-commerce platform that provides store owners with a wide range of features and tools to manage their online stores. One of the key features of Magento 2 is the ability to switch the language of the platform to better serve customers from different regions and cultures. Additionally, it also has a robust security feature, which includes how to unlock admin user in magento 2 if needed. By default, the Magento 2 admin panel is in English, but you can easily change it to a different language of your choice. 

This is an important aspect of localization, as it helps to create a more personalized and user-friendly experience for customers. In this blog, we will be discussing the process of how to change the language of Magento 2 admin panel in a step-by-step manner, making it easy for you to follow and implement. Whether you’re a beginner or an experienced user, you’ll find this guide helpful in switching to your preferred language and improving the customer experience on your online store.

Steps to change the language of magento 2 admin panel 

Method : 01

Step 1: 

Click your user Icon and then click and go to Account Settings.

Step 2:

Now find the Interface Locale Box in the Account Information Section where you can choose the language you need.

Step 3:

Now, enter your current password in the password field and then press the save account button to save the language of the admin panel in Magento 2.

Method : 02

Step 1: Install the language package

The first step is to install the language package you want to use in the Magento 2 admin panel. You can download the language packages from the Magento Marketplace or you can create your own language package.

Step 2: Log in to the Magento 2 admin panel

To change the language of the Magento 2 admin panel, you need to log in to the admin panel. Go to your store’s admin URL and enter your login credentials.

Step 3: Go to the Configuration section

Once you are logged in, click on the “Stores” option in the left-side menu, and then click on the “Configuration” option.

Step 4: Change the locale

In the Configuration section, go to the “General” tab and then to the “Locale Options” section. Here, you can change the locale to the language you want to use in the Magento 2 admin panel.

Step 5: Save the changes

After you have changed the locale, click on the “Save Config” button to save the changes. The language of the Magento 2 admin panel will be changed immediately.

Conclusion

Changing the language of the Magento 2 admin panel is a simple and straightforward process. By following the steps outlined above, you can easily switch to a different language and manage your online store in the language of your choice. If you encounter any problems or have any questions, please consult the Magento 2 documentation or contact the Magento support team for assistance.

nodes.title: How to Create a Zip File in Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: Zip files are an essential tool for managing and transferring multiple files and folders in a convenient and organized manner. In Magento 2, you can create zip files from the file manager in your backend with just a few simple steps. This process is essential for those who need to transfer large amounts of data, … Read more
nodes.content:
Zip files are an essential tool for managing and transferring multiple files and folders in a convenient and organized manner. In Magento 2, you can create zip files from the file manager in your backend with just a few simple steps. This process is essential for those who need to transfer large amounts of data, as zip files allow you to compress and package multiple files into a single file for easy storage and transfer. 

In this blog, we will go over the step-by-step process of how to create a zip file in Magento 2, including selecting the files, compressing them, renaming the file, and downloading it to your computer.

Steps to Create a Zip File in Magento 2

You can call the following function in .phtml file to create a zip file in Magento 2.

get Zip(‘D:\My Folder\E:\Web Guru\Logo.png’,’D:\zip\E:\Web Guru\logo.zip’)

OR

<?php 

namespace Vendor\Module\Block;

use Magento\Framework\Archive\Zip;

protected $zip;

public function construct(Context $context,Zip $zip)

    {

        $this->zip = $zip;

        parent::construct($context);

    }

 public function getZip()

 {

 $this->zip->pack('source_file_directory','target_zip_file_directory');

 }

In the above code:

– Replace the source_file_directory with the directory of the file you want to add into the zip. For e.g., E:\Web Guru\Logo.png

– Replace the target_zip_file_directory with the file path where you want to save the file with Zip extension. For e.g., E:\Web Guru\logo.zip

Conclusion

In conclusion, creating a zip file in Magento 2 is a simple and straightforward process that can greatly simplify your file management and transfer needs. With this guide, you will be able to create and download zip files, as well as install a theme from a zip file, in no time, making it easier to transfer and store large amounts of data. Whether you are a business owner, developer, or just need to transfer files regularly, this guide will provide you with the tools and knowledge you need to create, use, and install themes from zip files in Magento 2.

nodes.title: How to Auto Apply Coupon Code in Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is an extensively utilized e-commerce platform that offers a wide range of tools and functionalities to support merchants in developing their online store. Providing discounts and coupon codes to customers is a crucial factor in achieving success in online business as it can help increase sales and enhance customer satisfaction. Magento 2 offers … Read more
nodes.content:
Magento 2 is an extensively utilized e-commerce platform that offers a wide range of tools and functionalities to support merchants in developing their online store. Providing discounts and coupon codes to customers is a crucial factor in achieving success in online business as it can help increase sales and enhance customer satisfaction. Magento 2 offers the option to both create coupon code in Magento 2 as well as auto-apply them, making it convenient for merchants to provide discounts to their customers in a hassle-free way.

Our blog post aims to offer a comprehensive guide on how to auto apply coupon code in Magento 2, enabling merchants to provide discounts and promotional offers to their customers effortlessly. Automating this process can help merchants save valuable time while ensuring that the correct discounts are applied to each order, which can significantly impact driving sales and ultimately enhance the overall customer experience for online shoppers.

Steps to Auto Apply Coupon Codes in Magento 2

Step 1: Login to Magento 2 Backend

To begin, log in to the Magento 2 backend using your admin credentials.

Step 2: Navigate to Promotions > Cart Price Rules

Go to the “Promotions” section, and then click on “Cart Price Rules”.

Step 3: Create a New Rule

Click on the “Add New Rule” button to create a new discount rule.

Step 4: Configure Rule Settings

In the “Rule Information” section, enter a name for the rule and select a customer group. Then, set the “From” and “To” dates for the rule to be active.

Step 5: Add Conditions

Next, go to the “Conditions” section and select “If an item is FOUND”. Then, add the conditions for the coupon code.

Step 6: Add Actions

In the “Actions” section, select “Percent of product price discount” and enter the discount percentage.

Step 7: Save the Rule

Once you have finished configuring the rule, click on the “Save” button to save your changes.

Step 8: Test the Coupon Code

To test the coupon code, go to your Magento 2 frontend and add products to the cart. The coupon code should automatically apply to the order total.

Conclusion

In summary, the process of auto-applying coupon codes in Magento 2 is a straightforward and effective solution for merchants to offer discounts and promotions to their customers. By adhering to the guidelines provided in this blog, merchants can establish and modify a new rule to automatically apply coupon codes in their Magento 2 store.

Incorporating this feature can be a useful weapon in a merchant’s arsenal to increase customer engagement and enhance the overall shopping experience for their online customers. With the ease of generating and customizing auto-applying coupon codes in Magento 2, merchants can focus on other aspects of their business while still offering valuable discounts to their customers.

nodes.title: How to Create Coupon Codes in Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: Coupon codes are a proven marketing strategy for boosting sales and attracting customers to your online store. Magento 2 provides an intuitive platform for creating and managing coupon codes, offering a variety of options for setting conditions and discounts. In this blog, we will guide you through the process of creating a coupon code, from … Read more
nodes.content:
Coupon codes are a proven marketing strategy for boosting sales and attracting customers to your online store. Magento 2 provides an intuitive platform for creating and managing coupon codes, offering a variety of options for setting conditions and discounts. In this blog, we will guide you through the process of creating a coupon code, from logging in to your Magento 2 admin panel to testing the coupon code at checkout. 

With this comprehensive guide, you will be able to know how to create coupon codes in Magento 2 store with ease. And then after you will also be able to auto apply coupon code in your Magento store.

Steps to create Coupon Codes in Magento 2

Step 1: Log in to your Magento 2 Admin Panel

To access the coupon code feature, log in to your Magento 2 admin panel using your username and password.

Step 2: Navigate to Marketing > Promotions > Cart Price Rules

In the left-side menu, click on Marketing and then Promotions. Under the Promotions tab, click on Cart Price Rules. This is where you will create and manage your coupon codes.

Step 3: Create a New Cart Price Rule

Click on the “Add New Rule” button at the top right corner of the page. This will open the “New Cart Price Rule” page.

Step 4: Fill in the Required Information

Enter a descriptive name for your coupon code in the “Rule Name” field. In the “Customer Group” section, select the customer groups for which the coupon code will be valid. Then, set the “From” and “To” dates for when the coupon code will be active.

Step 5: Set the Coupon Code Conditions

In the “Conditions” section, select the conditions under which the coupon code will be valid. For example, you can set a minimum purchase amount, a specific product, or a category for the coupon code to be valid.

Step 6: Set the Coupon Code Actions

In the “Actions” section, select the discount type for your coupon code. You can choose from percent off, fixed amount, or free shipping. Then, enter the discount amount or percentage.

Step 7: Save the Cart Price Rule

Click on the “Save and Continue Edit” button at the top right corner of the page to save your coupon code.

Step 8: Test the Coupon Code

To test your coupon code, add a product to your cart and enter the coupon code at checkout. The discount should be applied to your order total.

That’s it! With these simple steps, you can easily create coupon codes in Magento 2 to drive sales and attract customers to your online store.

Conclusion

In conclusion, creating coupon codes in Magento 2 is a simple and effective way to drive sales and attract customers to your online store. By following the steps outlined in this blog, you can easily create and manage coupon codes that will increase the visibility of your store and provide a valuable incentive for customers to make a purchase. Whether you are a new or experienced Magento 2 user, this guide will help you create coupon codes that will drive sales and improve the success of your online store.

nodes.excerpt: In this article, we’ll discuss how to remove Magento 2 extension from your store if you’ve decided to do so. Fortunately, the process of removing a Magento 2 extension is straightforward, and we’ll guide you through the steps on how to uninstall Magento 2 extension successfully. Whether you no longer need a module or want … Read more
nodes.content:
In this article, we’ll discuss how to remove Magento 2 extension from your store if you’ve decided to do so. Fortunately, the process of removing a Magento 2 extension is straightforward, and we’ll guide you through the steps on how to uninstall Magento 2 extension successfully. Whether you no longer need a module or want to replace it with a different solution, we’ll show you how to remove the extension from your store. So, let’s dive in!

How to Remove Magento 2 Extension: A Comprehensive Guide

Removal using Composer (simple method)

Hey there, fellow Magento users! Are you wondering how to safely and securely remove an extension from your system? Well, you’re in luck because I have some advice for you!

Firstly, let me just say that the most secure way to install Magento 2.4 is through Composer. So if you haven’t already done that, I highly recommend it. Now, let’s move on to removing an extension.

There are two methods available: simple and complex. The simple method is suitable for extensions with no dependencies or connections to other extensions. However, if the extension you want to remove has dependencies and heavily affects your store, a more complex approach is required. Don’t worry though, I’ll walk you through both methods.

Let’s start with the simple method:

  1. Log into your domain via SSH/CLI and navigate to your store’s root.
  2. Run the command “bin/Magento module: status” to get a list of enabled modules and find the internal name of the module you want to remove (e.g. Webguru_Demo).
  3. Run the command “bin/Magento module: disable <Internal Module Name>” to disable the module.
  4. Run the command “bin/magento setup: upgrade” to remove the module from all store activities.
  5. Go to the root directory of the module you want to remove and find the “composer.json” file. In our example, it’s located at “/vendor/Webguru/module-demo/composer.json.” Find the “composer name” in the “name” attribute.
  6. Return to the store’s root and run the command “composer remove <composer name>” (e.g. composer remove Webguru/module-demo).

Now, if the extension you want to remove has dependencies and heavily affects your store, you’ll need to use the more complex method:

However, when the module has dependencies and heavily affects your store, a more complex approach is required.

Removing with Composer (complex)

How to remove Magento 2 extension depends on the complexity of the module. Complex removal is necessary for modules with dependencies or when the module is deeply integrated into your store, requiring maintenance mode during removal. it simplifies this process with a specific command:

1.Log into your domain via SSH/CLI and navigate to your store’s root.

2. Run the command “bin/Magento module: status” to get a list of enabled modules and find the internal name of the module you want to remove (e.g. Webguru_Demo).

3. Run the command “bin/Magento module: uninstall [options] <internal module name>” .

4. To automatically backup the database, add the option “–backup-db”. The tar-gzipped backup file will be located in the “/var/backup” directory.

5. To automatically backup all store media (in the “/pub/media” directory), add the option “–backup-media”. This will also be placed in the “/var/backup” directory.

6. To automatically backup the store code (useful for restoring the system after incorrect removal), add the option “–backup-code”. This will backup the entire store excluding temporary or generated directories and will also be placed in the “/var/backup” directory.

7. To automatically remove all tables created by the module, add the option “–remove-data”.

8. To automatically clean static files after removal, add the option “–clear-static-content”.

9. For example, if we want to backup the database and regenerate static content, the full command in our example would be “bin/magento module:uninstall –backup-db –clear-static-content Magento_Demo”

The command will halt if it encounters any dependencies and displays them to you.

bin/magento module:uninstall Webguru_Demo

Cannot uninstall module ‘Magento_Demo’ because the following module(s) depend on it:

Webguru_SampleData

In such cases, simply add the dependencies before the module name. The command would then look like this: bin/Magento module: uninstall –backup-db –clear-static-content Magento_SampleData Magento_Demo.

This command will automatically switch your store to maintenance mode, deactivate and remove the application, and clear the cache and data specified in the options. It will then run the composer removal command and upon completion, turn off the maintenance mode.

Manual Removal

If your store does not use Composer, you can remove the extension manually with the following steps:

1.Log in via SSH/CLI to your domain and navigate to the root of your store.

2. Run the command bin/Magento module: status to see a list of enabled modules, and identify the internal name of the module you want to remove (e.g. Webguru_Demo).

3. Run the command bin/Magento module: disable <Internal Module Name> (e.g. bin/Magento module: disable Webguru_Demo) to disable the module.

4. Run the command bin/magento setup: upgrade to remove the module from all store activities.

5. Remove the module directory with the command rm -rf <Module Directory>.

6. Clean the cache with bin/magento cache: clean and regenerate the static content with bin/magento setup:static-content: deploy -f.

Note: This manual removal method may result in unchecked errors, so it’s recommended to use Composer for uninstall extension Magento 2. By using Composer, you can ensure that all the dependencies of the extension are removed properly and there are no conflicts with other extensions.

Conclusion

In conclusion, the best and safest way to remove extensions is by using Composer. For simple extensions, the process is straightforward and can be accomplished by following a few steps. However, for complex extensions with dependencies, a more complex approach is recommended, This command automatically puts the store in maintenance mode, disables and removes the application, cleans the cache and all specified data, and runs the composer removal command. If you are wondering how to remove Magento 2 extension manually and your store does not use Composer, you can try to remove the extension manually, but this may result in unchecked errors. It is always recommended to use Composer for extension removal in it.
